But against this view there are certain objections that may be urged.

ln the first place, as Caesar approached Gergovia from the north, marching up the bank ot the Allier (34, ξ 2), it is perhaps natural to suppose that he attached the town horn that quarten unless we are told something to the contrary. ln the next place Caesar tells us that the hill be captured was ‘e regione oppidi’ (36, § 5). Now as a straight line can be drawn from any one point to any other, this description could not be employed intelligibly by Caesar except in refereme to some third point, which would presumably be his own camp. We are therefore led to inser that the hill captured lay in a straight line between Caesar's camp and the town. Napoleon’s plan however makes the small camp form the apex oi a triangle with a line between the oppidum and the large camp lor its base.
